title: Problem Overview
content: **Erdős Problem #370** asks whether infinitely many n exist such that both n and n+1 have their largest prime factor less than their square root. Steinerberger found an elegant solution using n = m² - 1.
mathContext: gpf(n) < √n means n is 'sqrt-smooth'. The problem asks about consecutive sqrt-smooth numbers.

title: Greatest Prime Factor
content: **gpf(n)** is the greatest prime factor of n, axiomatized with key properties: gpf(p) = p for primes, gpf(p^k) = p for prime powers, and gpf(ab) ≤ max(gpf(a), gpf(b)).
mathContext: gpf(n) = max{p : p prime, p | n}. Key property: gpf(ab) ≤ max(gpf(a), gpf(b)).

title: Smooth Numbers
content: **B-smooth** numbers have all prime factors ≤ B. **√-smooth** numbers have gpf(n) < √n. The main predicate **ConsecutiveSqrtSmooth(n)** captures when both n and n+1 are sqrt-smooth.
mathContext: IsSqrtSmooth(n) ≡ gpf(n) < √n. These are numbers whose largest prime factor is 'small' relative to the number.

title: Steinerberger Construction
content: **Key insight**: Take n = m² - 1 = (m-1)(m+1). Then n+1 = m², so gpf(n+1) = gpf(m). If m is a power of 2, gpf(m²) = 2 < m = √(m²). For n to work, we need gpf((m-1)(m+1)) < m.
mathContext: SteinerbergerConstruction(m) = m² - 1. The factorization (m-1)(m+1) controls the prime factors of n.

title: Example: n = 63
content: **Verified example**: n = 63 = 8² - 1 = 7·9. We have gpf(63) = 7 < √63 ≈ 7.94 and gpf(64) = 2 < √64 = 8. This demonstrates the Steinerberger construction works.
mathContext: 63 = 7·3², so gpf(63) = 7. 64 = 2⁶, so gpf(64) = 2. Both satisfy the sqrt-smooth condition.

title: Main Theorem
content: **Erdős #370 (SOLVED)**: There are infinitely many n with gpf(n) < √n and gpf(n+1) < √(n+1). The Steinerberger construction provides an infinite family of examples.
mathContext: The set {n : ConsecutiveSqrtSmooth(n)} is infinite. Powers of 2 give infinitely many valid m values.

title: Pomerance's Density Observation
content: **Pomerance noted**: If we replace exponent 1/2 with 1/√e - ε, the statement is true for density reasons. The critical exponent 1/√e ≈ 0.6065 comes from the Dickman function: half of integers have gpf ≤ n^{1/√e}.
mathContext: The Dickman function ρ(u) gives the density of u-smooth numbers. At u = √e, the density is 1/2.
